The Sri Lanka Government Gazette is an official publication of the Government of Sri Lanka that contains official notices, announcements, and gazette notifications. It is published weekly and is the official medium for the Government to communicate its intentions, policies, and decisions to the public.

The Sri Lanka Government Gazette publishes a wide range of information, including government appointments, tenders, auctions, public notices, legislative enactments, policy decisions, and other official announcements. It also publishes notifications related to land acquisitions, company registrations, and insolvency notices, among others.

The Sri Lanka Government Gazette can be accessed in print form from the Government Press, which is the official publisher of the gazette. Additionally, the gazette is also available online on the official website of the Government of Sri Lanka, where recent issues can be downloaded in PDF format. The Big Texan Steak House is a legendary restaurant located in Amarillo, Texas, USA. Known for its massive 72-oz steak challenge, it has become a popular tourist destination and a must-visit spot for meat lovers.

The Big Texan Steak House is situated in Amarillo, Texas, on the famous Route 66. Its address is 7701 Interstate 40 East, Amarillo, TX 79118. The restaurant is easily accessible from the highway, making it a convenient stop for travelers.

The 72-oz steak challenge at The Big Texan Steak House is a legendary eating contest that has been featured on numerous food and travel shows. Contestants have one hour to consume a 72-oz top sirloin steak, along with a side of shrimp cocktail, baked potato, salad, and roll. If they successfully finish the meal within the time limit, it's free; otherwise, they pay the regular price of over $70.

Ben Franklin was a renowned American polymath, statesman, scientist, writer, and diplomat. He was one of the Founding Fathers of the United States and played a key role in drafting the United States Constitution and the Declaration of Independence.

Ben Franklin's achievements are numerous and varied. He was a leading figure in the Enlightenment, and his scientific contributions include the invention of bifocal glasses, the lightning rod, and significant research in electricity. He was also a prolific writer, and his publications include Poor Richard's Almanack and The Way to Wealth. Franklin was a successful statesman, serving as the sixth President of Pennsylvania and later as the United States Ambassador to France.

Ben Franklin's legacy is profound and far-reaching. He is revered as a symbol of American ingenuity, curiosity, and civic engagement. His commitment to education, science, and public service has inspired generations of Americans. The University of Pennsylvania, which he founded, is a testament to his dedication to education. His iconic image appears on the $100 bill, and his name is synonymous with wisdom, wit, and innovation. Franklin's legacy continues to shape American culture, politics, and identity.

The Bradley Center is a multi-purpose arena located in Milwaukee, Wisconsin, United States. It was home to the Milwaukee Bucks of the National Basketball Association (NBA) and the Milwaukee Admirals of the American Hockey League (AHL) from 1988 to 2018.
The Bradley Center is situated in downtown Milwaukee, Wisconsin, at 1001 N. 4th St. It's easily accessible by car or public transportation, making it a convenient venue for events and concerts.

The Bradley Center hosts a wide range of events throughout the year, including NBA and AHL games, concerts, tennis matches, mixed martial arts events, and more. It has also been the site of several high-profile events, such as the NCAA Men's Basketball Championship and the US Figure Skating Championships.

The Brooklyn Bridge is a hybrid cable-stayed/suspension bridge in New York City that connects the boroughs of Brooklyn and Manhattan. It spans the East River and is one of the oldest and most iconic bridges in the United States. Completed in 1883, the Brooklyn Bridge was the longest suspension bridge in the world at the time of its opening.

The construction of the Brooklyn Bridge began in 1869 and took 14 years to complete. It was designed by John A. Roebling, a German-born engineer, and his son Washington Roebling. The bridge was officially opened on May 24, 1883, and was initially called the New York and Brooklyn Bridge or the East River Bridge.

The Brooklyn Bridge is not only a feat of engineering but also a cultural icon of New York City. It has been featured in numerous films, television shows, and works of literature, including in the works of Hart Crane, Walt Whitman, and Henry James. The bridge has also been a popular spot for tourists and locals alike, offering stunning views of the Manhattan skyline and the East River. It was designated as a National Historic Landmark in 1964 and is considered one of the greatest engineering achievements of the 19th century.

Butte is a city in Silver Bow County, Montana, United States. It is one of the largest cities in Montana and was once a major copper mining town. Butte was founded in 1864 as a small mining camp, and it quickly grew into a thriving town with a rich history.

Butte is known for its rich mining history, including being one of the largest copper producers in the world. The city is also home to the Berkeley Pit, a former open-pit copper mine that is now a popular tourist attraction. Additionally, Butte is famous for its historic architecture, including the Copper King Mansion, which was built in the late 1800s.

Butte offers a variety of activities and attractions for visitors. The city has a number of museums, including the Butte Mineral Museum and the Copper King Mansion Museum, which showcase the city's mining history. Visitors can also tour the Berkeley Pit, take a stroll down historic Main Street, or explore the surrounding mountains and forests. For outdoor enthusiasts, Butte offers plenty of opportunities for hiking, fishing, and skiing.

Canasta is a popular card game that originated in the 1940s in Uruguay and Argentina. It is a rummy-style game played with two to six players, and its name "canasta" means "basket" in Spanish. The game involves making sets and runs of cards, with the goal of being the first team to score 5,000 points.

A standard deck of Canasta cards consists of 108 cards, including 2 jokers and 4 suits of 24 cards each (Ace to 9, with two sets of cards 2-8 in each suit). The deck also includes 12 wild cards, which are 4 jokers and 8 deuces (2s). The remaining cards are divided into natural cards (Ace to 9) and wild cards.

Points are scored in Canasta by laying down sets and runs of cards. A set consists of three or four cards of the same rank, while a run consists of three or more cards of the same suit in sequential order (e.g., 3-4-5 of hearts). Jokers and deuces are wild and can be used as any card to complete a set or run. Each card has a point value, with jokers and twos worth 50 points, Aces worth 20 points, and other cards worth their face value. Bonus points are awarded for going out (laying down all the cards in a player's hand).

Carl Lewis is a former American track and field athlete who specialized in the sprint and long jump events. He is widely regarded as one of the greatest athletes of all time, winning 10 Olympic medals, including 9 gold medals, and 10 World Championship medals.

Carl Lewis is a legendary athlete with an impressive list of achievements. He won four consecutive Olympic gold medals in the long jump (1984-1996) and is the current world record holder in the 100m relay. He also won gold medals in the 100m and 4x100m relay at the 1984 and 1992 Olympics. Lewis was named the World Athlete of the Decade for the 1980s and was inducted into the USA Track & Field Hall of Fame in 2001.

Carl Lewis was born on July 1, 1961, in Birmingham, Alabama. He grew up in a athletic family, with his mother being a hurdler and his father a coach. Lewis attended the University of Houston, where he won numerous NCAA championships. After retiring from athletics, Lewis has remained involved in the sport, working as a track and field coach and analyst. He has also been involved in various philanthropic activities, including working with the Carl Lewis Foundation, which focuses on promoting youth fitness and education.

B. F. Skinner was an American psychologist, behaviorist, and philosopher who is widely regarded as one of the most influential psychologists of the 20th century. He was born on March 20, 1904, in Susquehanna, Pennsylvania, and died on August 18, 1990. Skinner is known for his work on operant conditioning, a type of learning in which behavior is modified by its consequences, such as rewards or punishments.

B. F. Skinner made several significant contributions to psychology, including the development of the operant conditioning chamber, also known as the "Skinner box." This device allowed Skinner to study behavior in a controlled environment and led to the discovery of key principles of operant conditioning, such as reinforcement, extinction, and punishment. Skinner also developed the concept of schedules of reinforcement, which describe the patterns of reinforcement that affect behavior. Additionally, he was a prolific writer and published numerous books, including "The Behavior of Organisms" and "Beyond Freedom and Dignity."

B. F. Skinner's work has had a significant impact on many areas of psychology and education. His principles of operant conditioning have been applied in educational settings to improve student behavior and learning outcomes. For example, teachers often use positive reinforcement, such as stickers or praise, to encourage good behavior and academic achievement. Skinner's work has also been applied in clinical settings to treat mental health disorders, such as anxiety and depression, and in organizational settings to improve employee performance and job satisfaction. Furthermore, Skinner's ideas have influenced the development of behavioral therapy and have been used to treat addiction and other behavioral problems.

Carolina is a region in the southeastern United States that consists of the states of North Carolina and South Carolina. The term "Carolina" originates from King Charles II of England, who granted a charter to eight English noblemen in 1663 to establish a colony in the region. Today, the Carolinas are known for their rich history, cultural heritage, and natural beauty, including the Blue Ridge Mountains and the Atlantic coastline.

The Carolinas are located in the southeastern United States, bordering the Atlantic Ocean to the east and the Appalachian Mountains to the west. North Carolina is situated in the northern part of the region, while South Carolina is located in the southern part. The two states share a border to the north and south, respectively, with Virginia and Georgia. Major cities in the Carolinas include Charlotte, Raleigh, and Greensboro in North Carolina, and Columbia, Charleston, and Greenville in South Carolina.

The Carolinas are known for their rich history, vibrant culture, and stunning natural beauty. The region is home to numerous historical sites, including the Wright Brothers National Memorial in Kitty Hawk, North Carolina, and Fort Sumter in Charleston, South Carolina, where the American Civil War began. The Carolinas are also famous for their barbecue, jazz and blues music, and collegiate sports, particularly basketball. Additionally, the region is a popular tourist destination, with attractions like the Biltmore Estate in Asheville, North Carolina, and Myrtle Beach, a popular resort town in South Carolina.

Charles Darwin was a British naturalist, biologist, and geologist who is best known for his theory of evolution through natural selection. He was born on February 12, 1809, in Shrewsbury, England, and died on April 19, 1882. Darwin's work on the Galapagos Islands and his observations of finches, tortoises, and other species led him to propose that all species of life have evolved over time through the process of variation, mutation, and selection.

Charles Darwin's most famous work is his book "On the Origin of Species," published in 1859. In this groundbreaking book, Darwin presented his theory of evolution through natural selection, which revolutionized the way people understood the natural world. The book is considered one of the most influential scientific works of the 19th century and is still widely read and studied today.

Charles Darwin played a crucial role in the development of modern evolutionary theory. His theory of evolution through natural selection provided a mechanism for understanding how species change and adapt over time. Darwin's work built on the ideas of earlier scientists, such as Jean-Baptiste Lamarck, and laid the foundation for modern evolutionary biology. His ideas have had a profound impact on fields such as biology, genetics, ecology, and anthropology, and continue to shape our understanding of the natural world.

Virginia Beach is an independent city located on the Atlantic coast of the United States in the state of Virginia. It is situated in the Hampton Roads metropolitan area, bordering the Elizabeth River to the north and the Atlantic Ocean to the east.

Virginia Beach is a popular tourist destination known for its warm climate, beaches, and outdoor recreational activities. Visitors can enjoy swimming, surfing, and sunbathing on the beach, as well as hiking and biking along the Virginia Beach Boardwalk. The city is also home to several attractions, including the Virginia Aquarium & Marine Science Center, the First Landing State Park, and the Mount Trashmore Park, which features a skate park, playgrounds, and a fishing lake.

Virginia Beach was established in 1607 as a seaside resort town, and it has a rich history dating back to the colonial era. The city played a significant role in the American Civil War and was later developed as a naval base during World War II. Today, Virginia Beach has a diverse economy, with major industries including tourism, military, and technology. The city is also home to several major military bases, including the Naval Air Station Oceana and the Dam Neck Annex. The economy is driven by a strong tourism industry, with millions of visitors flocking to the city each year to enjoy its beaches, attractions, and outdoor activities.

Coastal Carolina is a public liberal arts university located in Conway, South Carolina, United States. It was established in 1954 as Coastal Carolina College and became a university in 1993. The university offers a range of academic programs, including business, education, humanities, and sciences, and is known for its strong programs in marine science, golf management, and resort tourism.

Coastal Carolina University is situated in Conway, South Carolina, approximately 15 miles northwest of Myrtle Beach. The campus is nestled near the Atlantic coast, providing students with easy access to the beach and a range of outdoor recreational activities. The university's proximity to Myrtle Beach, a popular tourist destination, also offers opportunities for internships and job placement in the hospitality and tourism industries.

Coastal Carolina University's athletic teams, known as the Chanticleers, compete in the NCAA Division I Sun Belt Conference. The university's baseball team has won several national championships, including the 2016 College World Series title. The football team has also experienced success, winning conference championships and participating in postseason bowl games. In addition to baseball and football, Coastal Carolina's athletic programs include men's and women's basketball, soccer, volleyball, and other sports.

David Suchet is a British actor, best known for his iconic portrayal of Agatha Christie's fictional detective Hercule Poirot in the long-running ITV drama series Agatha Christie's Poirot. Born on May 2, 1946, in London, England, Suchet has had a distinguished career in film, television, and theater, with numerous award-winning performances to his credit.

David Suchet's most famous role is that of Hercule Poirot, the fastidious and intelligent Belgian detective created by Agatha Christie. Suchet played the role from 1989 to 2013, starring in 70 episodes and adapting 33 of Christie's novels and short stories. His performance as Poirot is widely regarded as one of the most authentic and engaging on screen, earning him numerous awards and nominations.

Throughout his career, David Suchet has won numerous awards for his performances. For his portrayal of Hercule Poirot, he won a BAFTA TV Award nomination for Best Actor, a Royal Television Society Award for Best Performance, and an National Television Award for Most Popular Actor. Additionally, he has been honored with an OBE (Order of the British Empire) for his services to drama. His other awards include a Variety Club Award for Best Actor, a Broadcasting Press Guild Award for Best Actor, and a TV Quick Award for Best Actor.

Disney Orlando, officially known as the Walt Disney World Resort, is a world-famous vacation resort located in Lake Buena Vista, Florida. It is owned and operated by The Walt Disney Company and is one of the most popular tourist destinations in the world. The resort spans over 25,000 acres and features four theme parks, two water parks, and over 30 resort hotels.

Disney Orlando is home to four theme parks: Magic Kingdom, Epcot, Hollywood Studios, and Animal Kingdom. Magic Kingdom is the first and most iconic of the four parks, featuring six themed lands and iconic attractions like Cinderella's Castle and Space Mountain. Epcot is a celebration of innovation, culture, and technological advancements from around the world, with two main areas: Future World and World Showcase. Hollywood Studios is dedicated to the world of movies, television, and music, with attractions like the Twilight Zone Tower of Terror and Star Wars: Galaxy's Edge. Animal Kingdom is a wildlife-themed park featuring attractions like Kilimanjaro Safaris and Avatar Flight of Passage.

There are countless things to do in Disney Orlando, but some of the most popular attractions and experiences include: watching the Happily Ever After fireworks display at Magic Kingdom, enjoying the Soarin' Around the World ride at Epcot, exploring the immersive Star Wars: Galaxy's Edge at Hollywood Studios, and taking a thrilling ride on the Expedition Everest roller coaster at Animal Kingdom. Visitors can also enjoy character meet-and-greets, parades, and live shows throughout the resort. Additionally, Disney Orlando offers a range of dining options, from quick-service restaurants to fine dining experiences, and a variety of shopping opportunities, from souvenir shops to upscale boutiques.

Ellis College was a private women's college located in Poughkeepsie, New York. It was founded in 1905 and offered a liberal arts education to women. The college was known for its strong programs in the arts, humanities, and social sciences.

Unfortunately, Ellis College closed its doors in 1974 due to financial difficulties. Despite its rich history and strong academic programs, the college was unable to sustain itself and was forced to close. The campus is now home to Marist College, a co-educational institution that has continued to build on the legacy of Ellis College.

Ellis College was proud to have a number of notable alumnae, including several accomplished women in the fields of art, literature, and education. One of its most notable alumni is the Pulitzer Prize-winning poet, Muriel Rukeyser, who graduated from Ellis College in 1930. Other notable alumnae include diplomats, politicians, and business leaders who went on to make significant contributions in their respective fields.

Bookwork refers to the written or printed work that a student or learner completes as part of their academic or vocational studies. It can include assignments, exercises, projects, and other written tasks that are intended to help the student learn and demonstrate their understanding of a particular subject or skill.

Examples of bookwork include math problems, English essays, science projects, and language translation exercises. It can also include worksheets, activity sheets, and other types of written assignments that are completed in a workbook or textbook. Additionally, bookwork can include longer-term projects, such as research papers, presentations, and literary analyses.

Bookwork is an essential part of the learning process because it helps students to develop their critical thinking, problem-solving, and communication skills. By completing bookwork, students can reinforce their understanding of new concepts, identify areas where they need more practice or review, and develop good study habits. Furthermore, bookwork helps teachers and instructors to assess student learning and provide feedback, which can inform instruction and improve student outcomes.

An e-loan, also known as an online loan, is a type of loan that is applied for, approved, and disbursed through the internet. With an e-loan, borrowers can submit their loan applications, provide required documents, and receive loan approvals and disbursements all online, without the need to physically visit a bank or financial institution.

A line of credit is a type of loan that allows borrowers to access a set amount of funds as needed, up to a maximum credit limit. Unlike a traditional loan, where the borrower receives a lump sum, a line of credit provides flexible access to funds, allowing borrowers to draw and repay funds as needed. Lines of credit can be secured or unsecured, and interest is typically only charged on the amount borrowed.

An e-loan line of credit combines the convenience of an online loan with the flexibility of a line of credit. With an e-loan line of credit, borrowers can apply online and, once approved, receive access to a revolving line of credit. They can then draw funds as needed, up to the approved credit limit, and repay the borrowed amount plus interest through online payments. This type of loan provides borrowers with easy access to funds, flexibility in repayment, and the convenience of online management.

Jack the Ripper was an unidentified serial killer who terrorized London's Whitechapel district in the late 19th century. Between 1888 and 1891, he murdered at least five prostitutes in brutal and violent attacks, mutilating their bodies and leaving behind a trail of bloodshed. Despite numerous investigations and suspects, the killer was never caught or identified, and his true identity remains one of the most enduring mysteries in criminal history.

Jack the Ripper's crimes were a series of gruesome murders that took place between August and November 1888. The canonical five victims were Mary Ann Nichols, Annie Chapman, Liz Stride, Catherine Eddowes, and Mary Jane Kelly. The killer targeted vulnerable women, often prostitutes, and attacked them in dark alleys or quiet streets. He would typically slit their throats, then mutilate their bodies, often removing organs such as the uterus or kidneys. The brutal and seemingly random nature of the crimes shocked the public and sparked widespread panic.

Over the years, numerous theories have emerged about the identity of Jack the Ripper, with some suspects gaining more attention than others. One popular theory is that the killer was a member of the British royal family, with Prince Albert Victor, Duke of Clarence and Avondale, being a prime suspect. Another theory points to Montague John Druitt, a lawyer who drowned himself in the Thames shortly after the last murder. Other suspects include Michael Ostrog, a Russian doctor; Francis Tumblety, an American quack doctor; and Aaron Kosminski, a Polish immigrant. Despite these theories, there is no concrete evidence to prove any of them, and the case remains unsolved.

Yugoslavia was a country located in Southeastern Europe that existed from 1918 to 2003. It was formed after World War I as the Kingdom of Serbs, Croats, and Slovenes, and it changed its name to the Kingdom of Yugoslavia in 1929. After World War II, it became the Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia, a socialist state led by Josip Broz Tito. Yugoslavia consisted of six republics and two autonomous provinces, and its capital city was Belgrade.

The six republics of Yugoslavia were Bosnia and Herzegovina, Croatia, Macedonia, Montenegro, Serbia, and Slovenia. Each republic had its own government and a degree of autonomy within the Yugoslav federation. The republics were established in 1946, and they played a crucial role in the country's political and economic development. The six republics were also home to diverse ethnic groups, including Bosniaks, Croats, Macedonians, Montenegrins, Serbs, and Slovenes, among others.

In the early 1990s, Yugoslavia began to dissolve, and the six republics declared independence. Slovenia and Croatia declared independence in 1991, followed by Bosnia and Herzegovina in 1992, Macedonia in 1993, and Montenegro and Serbia in 2006. The country's dissolution was marked by a series of violent conflicts, including the Slovenian independence war, the Croatian War of Independence, the Bosnian War, and the Kosovo War. Today, the six former republics of Yugoslavia are independent countries, each with its own government, economy, and international relations.

The Cuban Revolution of 1959 was led by Fidel Castro, Che Guevara, and the July 26 Movement. Fidel Castro, a young lawyer and charismatic leader, emerged as the key figure in the revolution. He, along with his brother Raúl Castro and Che Guevara, a Argentine Marxist revolutionary, formed the core of the revolutionary leadership.

The Cuban Revolution of 1959 was a series of key events that led to the overthrow of the authoritarian government of Fulgencio Batista. The revolution began on July 26, 1953, with an armed attack on the Batista regime's Moncada Barracks. Although the initial attack failed, it marked the beginning of the revolution. Over the next five years, Castro's July 26 Movement waged a guerrilla war against the Batista regime, culminating in the capture of Havana on January 8, 1959.

The Cuban Revolution of 1959 was driven by a desire for social and economic change. The revolutionaries sought to overthrow the corrupt and authoritarian Batista regime, which was seen as a puppet of American interests. The revolution was influenced by Marxist and socialist ideology, with the goal of establishing a socialist state in Cuba. The revolutionaries also sought to redistribute land, nationalize industries, and promote social justice and equality. The revolution's ideology was shaped by the writings of Marx, Lenin, and other socialist thinkers, as well as the experiences of other Latin American revolutions.

The standard axioms of set theory, also known as Zermelo-Fraenkel set theory (ZFC), are a set of nine axioms that form the foundation of modern set theory. These axioms were first proposed by Ernst Zermelo in 1908 and later developed by Abraham Fraenkel in the 1920s. The nine axioms of ZFC are: Extensionality, Pairing, Union, Power Set, Foundation, Choice, Infinity, Replacement, and Regularity.

The axioms of set theory provide a foundation for mathematics by establishing the rules and properties of sets, which are fundamental objects in mathematics. These axioms aim to formalize the intuitive notion of a set and its operations, allowing mathematicians to construct and manipulate sets in a consistent and rigorous way. By providing a rigorous framework, the axioms of set theory enable mathematicians to prove theorems and derive results in various areas of mathematics, such as algebra, analysis, and geometry.

The axioms of set theory have significant implications for various areas of mathematics and beyond. For instance, the Axiom of Choice, which asserts the existence of a choice function for any collection of non-empty sets, has far-reaching consequences in topology, analysis, and algebra. The axioms also lead to the development of cardinalities and ordinalities, which are essential in understanding infinite sets and their properties. Furthermore, the axioms of set theory have influenced the development of other areas of mathematics, such as category theory and type theory, and have applications in computer science, philosophy, and linguistics.

SemSearch_LS-39.original: ten ancient Greek city-kingdoms of Cyprus
expanded: Ancient Cyprus was a major hub of the ancient Greek world, with a rich history dating back to the 10th century BCE. The island was inhabited by various cultures, including the Mycenaeans, Achaeans, and Dorians, who established city-kingdoms that flourished until the Roman conquest in 58 BCE. Cyprus played a significant role in the Greek world, with its strategic location in the eastern Mediterranean making it a vital center for trade and commerce.

Ten major city-kingdoms existed in ancient Cyprus, each with its own distinct history and culture. These city-kingdoms were: Salamis, founded by the Mycenaeans; Kition, an important center of Phoenician influence; Idalion, famous for its copper mines; Curium, known for its stunning archaeological site; Tamassus, a major copper-producing center; Ledra, later renamed Lefkosia (modern-day Nicosia); Paphos, a city-kingdom associated with the goddess Aphrodite; Marion, known for its theatre and archaeological site; Soli, famous for its ancient theatre and mosaics; and Lapithos, a major center of Greek culture.

The city-kingdoms of ancient Cyprus were renowned for their achievements in various fields. Salamis was a major center of trade and commerce, while Kition was famous for its copper production and Phoenician architecture. Idalion was known for its stunning pottery, and Curium was a significant center of Greek philosophy. The city-kingdom of Paphos was associated with the worship of Aphrodite, and its archaeological site features stunning mosaics and architecture. The city-kingdoms of Marion and Soli were famous for their theatres, while Lapithos was a major center of Greek culture and learning. The city-kingdoms of ancient Cyprus played a significant role in the development of Greek civilization, and their legacy continues to fascinate historians and archaeologists today.

SemSearch_LS-4.original: Axis powers of World War II
expanded: The Axis powers of World War II consisted of three main countries: Germany, Italy, and Japan. These countries formed alliances with each other and coordinated their military efforts to fight against the Allied powers.

The Axis powers were united by a desire for territorial expansion, military conquest, and the creation of a "new order" in Europe and Asia. Germany, under the leadership of Adolf Hitler and the Nazi Party, sought to establish itself as the dominant power in Europe and eradicate the Jewish population. Italy, led by Benito Mussolini, aimed to create a fascist empire in the Mediterranean region. Japan, under the military government of Hideki Tojo, sought to expand its empire in East Asia and secure resources such as oil and raw materials.

The Axis powers were involved in several key events and milestones during World War II. In 1939, Germany invaded Poland, which led to the declaration of war by France and the United Kingdom. Italy declared war on France and the UK in 1940, while Japan attacked Pearl Harbor in 1941, drawing the United States into the conflict. The Axis powers experienced significant military successes in the early years of the war, but began to falter in 1942-1943. The Allies launched a series of counterattacks, including the D-Day invasion of Normandy and the Soviet Union's push into Eastern Europe, which ultimately led to the defeat of the Axis powers in 1945.

Born on January 31, 1956, in the Netherlands, van Rossum developed an interest in computer programming at an early age and went on to study computer science at the University of Amsterdam.

Guido van Rossum's motivation for creating Python was to develop a scripting language that was easy to learn and use, and that could be used for a wide range of applications. The Seven Wonders of the Ancient World are a list of remarkable constructions from antiquity that were considered the most impressive achievements of their time. The original list of Seven Wonders was compiled by ancient Greek historians and philosophers, and it includes the Great Pyramid of Giza, the Hanging Gardens of Babylon, the Statue of Zeus at Olympia, the Temple of Artemis at Ephesus, the Mausoleum at Halicarnassus, the Colossus of Rhodes, and the Lighthouse of Alexandria.

The ancient wonders were characterized by their massive scale, innovative engineering, and exquisite craftsmanship. They were often built to honor gods, commemorate important events, or showcase the wealth and power of rulers. Many of these wonders were also associated with mythological stories and legends, which added to their mystique and allure. For example, the Hanging Gardens of Babylon were said to have been built by the Neo-Babylonian king Nebuchadnezzar II for his Median wife, Queen Amytis, who missed the green hills and valleys of her homeland.

The ancient wonders continue to inspire wonder and awe in modern times, even though only one of the original Seven Wonders, the Great Pyramid of Giza, remains standing. They serve as testaments to the ingenuity, creativity, and perseverance of ancient civilizations, and they have had a profound impact on the development of architecture, art, and engineering. The ancient wonders also remind us of the importance of preserving cultural heritage and protecting our shared cultural legacy for future generations. In 2007, a new list of the Seven Wonders of the World was compiled through a worldwide poll, which included wonders such as the Great Wall of China, the Taj Mahal, and Machu Picchu.

The United States Armed Forces are organized into five main branches: the Army, Navy, Air Force, Marine Corps, and Coast Guard. These branches are responsible for protecting the country and its interests through various military operations and activities.

The Army is responsible for land-based military operations, including combat missions and peacekeeping efforts. The Navy is responsible for naval operations, including sea-based defense and power projection. The Air Force is responsible for air-based operations, including combat, transportation, and reconnaissance. The Marine Corps is a rapid-response force that specializes in amphibious warfare and expeditionary operations. Eastern Orthodox monasticism is a tradition of asceticism and prayer within the Eastern Orthodox Church, characterized by a commitment to a life of renunciation, simplicity, and devotion to God. It is rooted in the early Christian Church and has been an integral part of Orthodox spirituality for centuries. Orthodox monks and nuns live in monasteries or convents, following a daily routine of prayer, work, and study, and are guided by a spiritual father or mother.

In the Eastern Orthodox Church, there are three main stages of monasticism, each representing a deeper level of commitment and spiritual growth. The first stage is the novice ( díkaios or rasophore), which is a period of testing and discernment for those seeking to enter monastic life. The second stage is the rassophore monk or nun, who has taken vows of obedience, chastity, and poverty, but has not yet made a lifelong commitment. The final stage is the stavrrophore monk or nun, also known as the "cross-bearer," who has made a lifelong commitment to monasticism and has received the tonsure, a ritual of haircutting signifying their renunciation of the world.

The great schema (megaschema) is the highest degree of monasticism in the Eastern Orthodox Church, reserved for those who have demonstrated extraordinary spiritual achievement and dedication. It is a symbol of complete renunciation of the world and a total commitment to God. Monks or nuns who have reached this stage have typically spent many years in monastic life, have demonstrated exceptional spiritual maturity, and have been recognized by their superiors as worthy of this highest honor. The great schema is characterized by a distinctive habit and a deeper level of asceticism, prayer, and service to others. It is a rare and esteemed achievement in the Orthodox Church.

Dr. Natarajan, a pioneer in the field of artificial intelligence, was awarded for her contributions to promoting women in technology.

The selection criteria for the ACM Athena award include exceptional technical leadership, vision, and commitment to helping women in the field of computer science. The award committee considers a range of factors, including the nominee's technical achievements, leadership roles, and contributions to increasing the representation of women in computing. The committee also looks for evidence of the nominee's impact on the community, such as mentoring, outreach, and advocacy efforts.

TREC_Entity-20.original: Scotch whisky distilleries on the island of Islay.
expanded: Islay is a small island located off the west coast of Scotland, in the Inner Hebrides. It is the southernmost of the Hebridean Islands and is known for its natural beauty, rich history, and, of course, its whisky. The island is approximately 25 miles long and 15 miles wide, and is home to around 3,000 people.

There are currently nine active whisky distilleries on the island of Islay. These are: Ardbeg, Bowmore, Bruichladdich, Bunnahabhain, Caol Ila, Kilchoman, Lagavulin, Laphroaig, and Port Ellen. Each of these distilleries has its own unique character and produces a distinctive style of whisky, ranging from the peaty and smoky to the smooth and sweet.

Islay whiskies are renowned for their smoky, peaty flavors, which are due to the island's unique geology and the traditional method of drying malted barley over peat fires. This gives the whiskies a distinctive flavor profile that is often described as complex, balanced, and full-bodied. Some popular examples of Islay whiskies include Laphroaig 10 Year Old, Ardbeg Uigeadail, and Lagavulin 16 Year Old. These whiskies are highly prized by connoisseurs and are often enjoyed neat or with a small amount of water to bring out their full flavor.

Philadelphia is home to teams in four major professional sports leagues: the National Football League (NFL), Major League Baseball (MLB), the National Basketball Association (NBA), and the National Hockey League (NHL).
The Philadelphia Eagles are the city's NFL team, playing their home games at Lincoln Financial Field. Founded in 1933, the Eagles have won four NFL championships and have a dedicated fan base.

The Philadelphia Phillies are the city's MLB team, playing their home games at Citizens Bank Park. Founded in 1883, the Phillies have won two World Series titles. The Philadelphia 76ers are the city's NBA team, playing their home games at the Wells Fargo Center. Founded in 1946, the 76ers have won three NBA championships. The Philadelphia Flyers are the city's NHL team, also playing their home games at the Wells Fargo Center. Founded in 1967, the Flyers have won two Stanley Cup championships.

Medimmune, Inc. is a biotechnology company that develops and commercializes pharmaceutical products, primarily in the areas of respiratory, inflammatory, and autoimmune diseases. The company was founded in 1988 and is headquartered in Gaithersburg, Maryland.

Medimmune's research and development efforts are focused on several therapeutic areas, including respiratory diseases, such as asthma and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD); inflammatory diseases, such as rheumatoid arthritis and inflammatory bowel disease; and autoimmune diseases, such as lupus and multiple sclerosis.

Medimmune has developed several notable products, including Synagis, a medication for the prevention of serious lower respiratory tract disease caused by respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) in high-risk infants; FluMist, a nasal spray vaccine for the prevention of influenza; and Benlysta, a treatment for systemic lupus erythematosus. Medimmune has also developed several pipeline products, including treatments for asthma, COPD, and inflammatory diseases.

The Nobel Prize in Physics is awarded by the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences, a prestigious scientific organization based in Stockholm, Sweden. The Academy was founded in 1739 and is responsible for selecting the Nobel laureates in Physics every year.

The Nobel Prize in Chemistry is awarded by the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences, the same organization that awards the Nobel Prize in Physics. The Academy's Committee for Chemistry is responsible for selecting the winners of the chemistry prize.

The Nobel Prize in Literature is awarded by the Swedish Academy, a separate organization from the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences. The Swedish Academy is responsible for selecting the Nobel laureate in Literature every year. The Nobel Peace Prize is awarded by the Norwegian Nobel Committee, a group of five members appointed by the Norwegian Parliament. The Sveriges Riksbank Prize in Economic Sciences in Memory of Alfred Nobel, commonly referred to as the Nobel Prize in Economics, is awarded by the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences, but is not one of the original prizes established by Alfred Nobel's will.

TREC_Entity-7.original: Airlines that currently use Boeing 747 planes.
expanded: The Boeing 747 is a wide-body commercial airliner that comes in several variants, including the 747-100, 747-200, 747-300, 747-400, 747-8, and others. These variants have different capacity, range, and engine options, but all share the iconic design and features of the 747 family.

Many airlines have operated the Boeing 747 over the years, including major carriers like British Airways, Lufthansa, Japan Airlines, and United Airlines. These airlines have used the 747 for both passenger and cargo operations, and some have even customized their 747s with unique liveries and interior configurations.

Although several airlines have retired their 747 fleets in recent years, some still operate the type. As of 2022, airlines like Lufthansa, Korean Air, and Asiana Airlines continue to fly the 747-400 and 747-8 variants. These airlines have chosen to retain the 747 due to its high capacity, reliability, and passenger appeal, particularly on high-demand routes.

TREC_Entity-9.original: Members of The Beaux Arts Trio.
expanded: The Beaux Arts Trio was founded in 1955 by pianist Menahem Pressler, along with violinist Daniel Guilet and cellist Bernard Greenhouse.
In addition to Menahem Pressler, the original members of The Beaux Arts Trio included violinist Daniel Guilet and cellist Bernard Greenhouse.
Over the years, the membership of The Beaux Arts Trio changed, with Isidore Cohen replacing Daniel Guilet as violinist in 1969, and Peter Wiley replacing Bernard Greenhouse as cellist in 1987.
